sn54.8:1.1.pli: “Ānāpānassatisamādhi, bhikkhave, bhāvito bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso.
sn54.8:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

sn54.8:1.2.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvito ca, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhi kathaṃ bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso?

sn54.8:2.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn54.8:2.1.eng: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

sn54.8:2.2.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

sn54.8:2.3.eng: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’ …

sn54.8:2.4.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.8:2.5.pli: Evaṃ bhāvito kho, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhi evaṃ bahulīkato mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso.
sn54.8:2.5.eng: That’s how immersion due to mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.

sn54.8:3.1.pli: Ahampi sudaṃ, bhikkhave, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddho bodhisattova samāno iminā vihārena bahulaṃ viharāmi.
sn54.8:3.1.eng: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too usually practiced this kind of meditation.

sn54.8:3.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, iminā vihārena bahulaṃ viharato neva kāyo kilamati na cakkhūni;
sn54.8:3.2.eng: And while I was usually practicing this kind of meditation neither my body nor my eyes became fatigued.

sn54.8:3.3.pli: anupādāya ca me āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci.
sn54.8:3.3.eng: And my mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.

sn54.8:4.2.pli: ‘neva me kāyo kilameyya na cakkhūni, anupādāya ca me āsavehi cittaṃ vimucceyyā’ti,
sn54.8:4.2.eng: ‘May neither my body nor my eyes became fatigued. And may my mind be freed from the defilements by not grasping.’

sn54.8:4.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:5.2.eng: ‘May I give up memories and thoughts tied to domestic life.’

sn54.8:5.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:6.2.eng: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive.’

sn54.8:6.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:7.2.eng: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive.’

sn54.8:7.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:8.2.eng: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive.’

sn54.8:8.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:9.2.eng: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive.’

sn54.8:9.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:10.2.pli: ‘appaṭikūlañca paṭikūlañca tadubhayaṃ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako vihareyyaṃ sato sampajāno’ti,
sn54.8:10.2.eng: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, shunning both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.’

sn54.8:10.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:11.2.pli: ‘vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
sn54.8:11.2.eng: ‘Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, may I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.’

sn54.8:11.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:12.2.pli: ‘vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
sn54.8:12.2.eng: ‘As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, may I enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.’

sn54.8:12.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:13.2.pli: ‘pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihareyyaṃ sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeyyaṃ, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti—upekkhako satimā sukhavihārīti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
sn54.8:13.2.eng: ‘With the fading away of rapture, may I enter and remain in the third absorption, where I will meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.”’

sn54.8:13.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:14.2.pli: ‘sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
sn54.8:14.2.eng: ‘With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, may I enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.’

sn54.8:14.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:15.2.pli: ‘sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
sn54.8:15.2.eng: ‘Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that “space is infinite”, may I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.’

sn54.8:15.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:16.2.pli: ‘sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
sn54.8:16.2.eng: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that “consciousness is infinite”, may I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.’

sn54.8:16.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:17.2.pli: ‘sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
sn54.8:17.2.eng: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that “there is nothing at all”, may I enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.’

sn54.8:17.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:18.2.eng: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, may I enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

sn54.8:18.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:19.2.eng: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, may I enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.’

sn54.8:19.3.eng: So let them closely focus on this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing.

sn54.8:20.1.pli: Evaṃ bhāvite kho, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhimhi evaṃ bahulīkate, sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti;
sn54.8:20.1.eng: When immersion due to mindfulness of breathing has been developed and cultivated in this way, if they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn54.8:20.2.pli: dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti;
sn54.8:20.2.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn54.8:20.3.pli: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
sn54.8:20.3.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.

sn54.8:21.1.pli: Sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati;
sn54.8:21.1.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.

sn54.8:21.2.pli: dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati;
sn54.8:21.2.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.

sn54.8:21.3.pli: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati.
sn54.8:21.3.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.

sn54.8:21.4.pli: So kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti,
sn54.8:21.4.eng: Feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn54.8:21.5.pli: ‘kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
sn54.8:21.5.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’

sn54.8:22.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, telañca paṭicca, vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyeyya,
sn54.8:22.1.eng: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

sn54.8:22.2.pli: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā anāhāro nibbāyeyya;
sn54.8:22.2.eng: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to not being fed.

sn54.8:22.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti, jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti,
sn54.8:22.3.eng: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn54.8:22.4.pli: ‘kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn54.8:22.4.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life has come to an end, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’”

sn54.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn54.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn54.9:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ anekapariyāyena asubhakathaṃ katheti, asubhāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, asubhabhāvanāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn54.9:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha spoke in many ways to the mendicants about the meditation on ugliness. He praised the meditation on ugliness and its development.

sn54.9:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

sn54.9:2.2.eng: “Mendicants, I wish to go on retreat for a fortnight.

sn54.9:2.3.pli: Nāmhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakenā”ti.
sn54.9:2.3.eng: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my almsfood.”

sn54.9:2.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā nāssudha koci bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamati, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakena.
sn54.9:2.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. And no-one approached him, except for the one who brought the almsfood.

sn54.9:3.2.pli: “bhagavā anekapariyāyena asubhakathaṃ katheti, asubhāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, asubhabhāvanāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatī”ti anekākāravokāraṃ asubhabhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā viharanti.
sn54.9:3.2.eng: “The Buddha spoke in many ways about the meditation on ugliness. He praised the meditation on ugliness and its development.” They committed themselves to developing the many different facets of the meditation on ugliness.

sn54.9:3.3.pli: Te iminā kāyena aṭṭīyamānā harāyamānā jigucchamānā satthahārakaṃ pariyesanti.
sn54.9:3.3.eng: Becoming horrified, repelled, and disgusted with this body, they looked for a suicide weapon.

sn54.9:3.4.pli: Dasapi bhikkhū ekāhena satthaṃ āharanti, vīsampi …pe… tiṃsampi bhikkhū ekāhena satthaṃ āharanti.
sn54.9:3.4.eng: Each day ten, twenty, or thirty mendicants committed suicide.

sn54.9:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa aḍḍhamāsassa accayena paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
sn54.9:4.1.eng: Then after a fortnight had passed, the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed Ānanda,

sn54.9:4.2.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, ānanda, tanubhūto viya bhikkhusaṅgho”ti?
sn54.9:4.2.eng: “Ānanda, why does the mendicant Saṅgha seem so diminished?”

sn54.9:4.3.pli: “Tathā hi pana, bhante, ‘bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ anekapariyāyena asubhakathaṃ katheti, asubhāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, asubhabhāvanāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatī’ti anekākāravokāraṃ asubhabhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā viharanti.
sn54.9:4.3.eng: Ānanda told the Buddha all that had happened, and said,

sn54.9:4.4.pli: Te iminā kāyena aṭṭīyamānā harāyamānā jigucchamānā satthahārakaṃ pariyesanti.

sn54.9:4.5.pli: Dasapi bhikkhū ekāhena satthaṃ āharanti, vīsampi bhikkhū … tiṃsampi bhikkhū ekāhena satthaṃ āharanti.

sn54.9:4.6.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā aññaṃ pariyāyaṃ ācikkhatu yathāyaṃ bhikkhusaṅgho aññāya saṇṭhaheyyā”ti.
sn54.9:4.6.eng: “Sir, please explain another way the mendicant Saṅgha might be settled in enlightenment.”

sn54.9:5.1.pli: “Tenahānanda, yāvatikā bhikkhū vesāliṃ upanissāya viharanti te sabbe upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannipātehī”ti.
sn54.9:5.1.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, gather all the mendicants staying in the vicinity of Vesālī together in the assembly hall.”

sn54.9:5.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā yāvatikā bhikkhū vesāliṃ upanissāya viharanti te sabbe upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannipātetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn54.9:5.2.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. He did what the Buddha asked, went up to him, and said,

sn54.9:5.4.eng: Please, sir, come at your convenience.”

sn54.9:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena upaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn54.9:6.1.eng: Then the Buddha went to the assembly hall, sat down on the seat spread out,

sn54.9:6.3.pli: “ayampi kho, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhi bhāvito bahulīkato santo ceva paṇīto ca asecanako ca sukho ca vihāro uppannuppanne ca pāpake akusale dhamme ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasameti.
sn54.9:6.3.eng: “Mendicants, when this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s peaceful and sublime, a delectable and blissful meditation. And it disperses and settles unskillful qualities on the spot whenever they arise.

sn54.9:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gimhānaṃ pacchime māse ūhataṃ rajojallaṃ, tamenaṃ mahāakālamegho ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasameti;
sn54.9:7.1.eng: In the last month of summer, when the dust and dirt is stirred up, a large sudden storm disperses and settles it on the spot.

sn54.9:7.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhi bhāvito bahulīkato santo ceva paṇīto ca asecanako ca sukho ca vihāro uppannuppanne ca pāpake akusale dhamme ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasameti.
sn54.9:7.2.eng: In the same way, when this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s peaceful and sublime, a delectable and blissful meditation. And it disperses and settles unskillful qualities on the spot whenever they arise.

sn54.9:7.3.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvito ca, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhi kathaṃ bahulīkato santo ceva paṇīto ca asecanako ca sukho ca vihāro uppannuppanne ca pāpake akusale dhamme ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasameti?
sn54.9:7.3.eng: And how is it so developed and cultivated?

sn54.9:8.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn54.9:8.1.eng: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

sn54.9:8.2.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out. …

sn54.9:8.3.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

sn54.9:8.4.pli: Evaṃ bhāvito kho, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhi evaṃ bahulīkato santo ceva paṇīto ca asecanako ca sukho ca vihāro uppannuppanne ca pāpake akusale dhamme ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasametī”ti.
sn54.9:8.4.eng: That’s how this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated so that it’s peaceful and sublime, a delectable and blissful  meditation. And it disperses and settles unskillful qualities on the spot whenever they arise.”

sn55.1:1.3.pli: “kiñcāpi, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī catunnaṃ dīpānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāretvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ, so tattha nandane vane accharāsaṅghaparivuto dibbehi ca pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, so catūhi dhammehi asamannāgato, atha kho so aparimuttova nirayā aparimutto tiracchānayoniyā aparimutto pettivisayā aparimutto apāyaduggativinipātā.
sn55.1:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a wheel-turning monarch were to rule as sovereign lord over these four continents. And when his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the thirty-three. There he entertains himself in the Garden of Delight, escorted by a band of nymphs, and supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation. Still, as he’s lacking four things, he’s not exempt from hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm. He’s not exempt from places of loss, bad places, the underworld.

sn55.1:1.4.pli: Kiñcāpi, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako piṇḍiyālopena yāpeti, nantakāni ca dhāreti, so catūhi dhammehi samannāgato, atha kho so parimutto nirayā parimutto tiracchānayoniyā parimutto pettivisayā parimutto apāyaduggativinipātā.
sn55.1:1.4.eng: Now suppose a noble disciple wears rags and feeds on scraps of almsfood. Still, as they have four things, they’re exempt from hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm. They’re exempt from places of loss, bad places, the underworld.

sn55.1:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti:
sn55.1:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha:

sn55.1:2.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
sn55.1:2.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn55.1:2.4.eng: They have experiential confidence in the teaching:

sn55.1:2.5.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
sn55.1:2.5.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

sn55.1:2.6.eng: They have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:

sn55.1:2.7.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ—cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā, esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
sn55.1:2.7.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

sn55.1:2.8.pli: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi acchiddehi asabalehi akammāsehi bhujissehi viññuppasatthehi aparāmaṭṭhehi samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.1:2.8.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

sn55.1:2.9.eng: These are the four qualities that they possess.

sn55.1:2.10.pli: Yo ca, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ dīpānaṃ paṭilābho, yo catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābho catunnaṃ dīpānaṃ paṭilābho catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭilābhassa kalaṃ nāgghati soḷasin”ti.
sn55.1:2.10.eng: And, mendicants, gaining these four continents is not worth a sixteenth part of gaining these four things.”

sn55.10:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn55.10:1.2.eng: “Sir, the layman named Kakkaṭa has passed away in Ñātika.

sn55.10:1.3.eng: Where has he been reborn in his next life?

sn55.10:1.10.pli: subhaddo nāma, bhante, ñātike upāsako kālaṅkato;
sn55.10:1.10.eng: Subhadda have passed away in Ñātika.

sn55.10:1.11.eng: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”

sn55.10:2.1.pli: “Kakkaṭo, ānanda, upāsako kālaṅkato pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.

sn55.10:2.8.pli: subhaddo, ānanda, upāsako kālaṅkato pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
sn55.10:2.8.eng: and Subhadda passed away having ended the five lower fetters. They’ve been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

sn55.10:3.1.pli: Paropaññāsa, ānanda, ñātike upāsakā kālaṅkatā pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
sn55.10:3.1.eng: Over fifty laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended the five lower fetters. They’ve been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

sn55.10:3.2.pli: Sādhikanavuti, ānanda, ñātike upāsakā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmino; sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karissanti.
sn55.10:3.2.eng: More than ninety laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. They’re once-returners, who will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

sn55.10:3.3.pli: Chātirekāni kho, ānanda, pañcasatāni ñātike upāsakā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
sn55.10:3.3.eng: More than five hundred laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters. They’re stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.10:4.1.pli: Anacchariyaṃ kho panetaṃ, ānanda, yaṃ manussabhūto kālaṃ kareyya;
sn55.10:4.1.eng: It’s no wonder that a human being should pass away.

sn55.10:4.2.pli: tasmiṃ tasmiñce maṃ kālaṅkate upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ paṭipucchissatha. Vihesā pesā, ānanda, assa tathāgatassa.
sn55.10:4.2.eng: But if you should come and ask me about it each and every time someone passes away, that would be a bother for me.

sn55.10:4.3.pli: Tasmātihānanda, dhammādāsaṃ nāma dhammapariyāyaṃ desessāmi; yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.10:4.3.eng: So Ānanda, I will teach you the explanation of the Dhamma named ‘the mirror of the teaching’. A noble disciple who has this may declare of themselves:

sn55.10:4.4.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’.
sn55.10:4.4.eng: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’

sn55.10:5.1.pli: Katamo ca so, ānanda, dhammādāso dhammapariyāyo; yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.10:5.1.eng: And what is that mirror of the teaching?

sn55.10:5.2.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’.

sn55.10:6.1.pli: Idhānanda, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
sn55.10:6.1.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.10:6.4.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.10:6.4.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.10:6.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, ānanda, dhammādāso dhammapariyāyo;
sn55.10:6.5.eng: This is that mirror of the teaching.

sn55.10:6.6.pli: yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
sn55.10:6.6.eng: A noble disciple who has this may declare of themselves:

sn55.10:6.7.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’”ti.
sn55.10:6.7.eng: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’”

sn55.11:0.3.eng: A Saṅgha of a Thousand Nuns

sn55.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati rājakārāme.
sn55.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Royal Monastery.

sn55.11:1.2.pli: Atha kho sahassabhikkhunisaṅgho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho tā bhikkhuniyo bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.11:1.2.eng: Then a Saṅgha of a thousand nuns went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. The Buddha said to them:

sn55.11:2.1.pli: “Catūhi kho, bhikkhuniyo, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.11:2.1.eng: “Nuns, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.11:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhuniyo, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.11:2.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.11:2.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.11:2.7.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti, akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.11:2.7.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.11:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhuniyo, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn55.11:2.8.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.12:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, the brahmins advocate a practice called ‘get up and go’.

sn55.12:1.4.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, kālasseva uṭṭhāya pācīnamukho yāhi.
sn55.12:1.4.eng: ‘Please, good people, rising early you should face east and walk.

sn55.12:1.5.pli: So tvaṃ mā sobbhaṃ parivajjehi, mā papātaṃ, mā khāṇuṃ, mā kaṇḍakaṭhānaṃ, mā candaniyaṃ, mā oḷigallaṃ.
sn55.12:1.5.eng: Do not avoid a pit, a cliff, a stump, thorny ground, a swamp, or a sewer.

sn55.12:1.6.eng: You should await death in the place that you fall.

sn55.12:1.7.pli: Evaṃ tvaṃ, ambho purisa, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissasī’ti.
sn55.12:1.7.eng: And when your body breaks up, after death, you’ll be reborn in a good place, a heaven realm.’

sn55.12:2.1.pli: Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇānaṃ bālagamanametaṃ mūḷhagamanametaṃ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn55.12:2.1.eng: But this practice of the brahmins is a foolish procedure, a stupid procedure. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, or extinguishment.

sn55.12:2.2.pli: Ahañca kho, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye udayagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ paññāpemi;
sn55.12:2.2.eng: But in the training of the Noble One I advocate a ‘get up and go’ practice

sn55.12:2.3.pli: yā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
sn55.12:2.3.eng: which does lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

sn55.12:3.1.pli: Katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, udayagāminī paṭipadā;
sn55.12:3.1.eng: And what is that ‘get up and go’ practice?

sn55.12:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.12:3.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.12:3.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti;

sn55.12:3.7.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.12:3.7.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.12:3.8.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, udayagāminī paṭipadā ekantanibbidāya …pe…
sn55.12:3.8.eng: This is that ‘get up and go’ practice

sn55.12:3.9.eng: which does lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”
